With apologies to Cato the Elder, “GOP delenda est.”

Cato stood in the Roman Senate and said this about Carthage every day for 20 years, until it came to pass, and I will say it every day here in the pages of The Times until it comes to pass.

The time to overthrow the Republican obstructionist tyranny that is killing our states and our country is NOW. We cannot wait until the redistricting of 2020 following the next census. The answer now is to work every day in every state to register Democratic voters, even and most especially where the voting laws are being rigged to suppress them, and then to get all Democrats to the polls every election day, beginning in 2014. Registration should be on-going, NOW, but most organizations such as OFA quit the day after the 2012 election. Even today, the new OFA is concerned only with "issues" and getting Obama's agenda passed, not with voter registration. This is short-sighted; none of Obama's agenda will be passed by this Republican Congress.

As our problems are caused by manipulations of voting, so is our solution possible only through voting. The power of GOP gerrymandering is not limitless, and there are enough unregistered or disaffected potential voters in most voting districts to overcome any gerrymandering scheme. In that way, and no other, lies the salvation of the country. This must be the primary mission of the Democratic Party, and of all thinking Americans, male and female, in every state.

All the gauzy nostalgia for the Clintons occupying 1600 Pennsylvanue Ave. tends to lose sight of the fact that Bill Clinton didn't win a majority of the popular vote in either 1992 or '96 and that he, as much as anyone, was responsible for Newt Gingrich becoming speaker of the House, followed by not one, but two government shutdowns.

Just as the historical momentum of having the first African-American president was the best thing Barack Obama had going for him in 2008, combined with his rhetorical ability and Bush fatigue, the prospect of the first female president is the overarching rationale for a Hillary Clinton candidacy. Little else. Certainly not her skill at running a campaign or inspiring the masses or preventing her inner circle from turning into a snakepit or, for that matter, managing a Cabinet department.

Mrs. Clinton entered the White House as a tag-along in January '93 and, for all intents and purposes, would be a tag-along again in January '17. In the word "Billary," the accent is -- and always has been -- on the first syllable. It's clear who's calling the shots. So let's be careful what we wish for.

Art has two faces: On the one hand, to the knowledgable viewer,  a work of art opens a world, as Heidegger argues in his famous essay on art. On the other hand, the knowledgable viewer, and especially the connoisseur of art, a Berenson, for example, can make use of his knowledge to earn huge sums of money. In doing so, the monetary value of the art judged to be authentic or worthy, soars, supporting museums whose patrons frequently arrive out of fascination at the prospect of viewing objects worth so much money. Art as an object in our consumer society is thus divested of its value as entry to a special world. And yet, both dimensions can co-exist despite the apparent contradictions. That is part of the fascination, and why we are interested in Danto and other philosophers of art.

I don't understand how Congress could CUT food stamps. They want Americans, especially children, the elderly and disabled to go hungry and be malnourished?

Since the recession and I guess until Congress voted to cut SNAP, we spent .27% of the GDP after 2007. But mention food stamps and immediately someone claims they saw someone purchase 20 lobsters with food stamps.

We have serious moral issues in this country if we're willing to let our most vulnerable go hungry. We also have serious national security issues -- children who grow up in poverty and don't do well in school will grow up into adults most likely to repeat the cycle of poverty and be incarcerated, which contributes nothing to our economy and in fact becomes a big expense.

And in terms of Mr. Kristof's quote: "...we may get more bang for the buck when we chip away at long-term poverty through early education, home visitation for infants, job training and helping teenagers avoid unwanted pregnancies" -- we don't seem to do much to address long-term poverty either.

I make these replies to my interlocutors:

Dear Arun: I don't know how may years ago you means. I trust that it wouldn't have been prior to the onset of the instant financial crisis in 2008. At that time, most credible economist did not think that the crisis required the bold steps that Professors Krugman and Summers prescribe today. But, as Professor Krugman, acknowledged at this blog, Professor Summers has been an advocate in writing of unconventional, expansive monetary policy for some time now and well in advance of his consideration for the Fed Chairmanship.

As for political savviness, no one heard a peep from Janet Yellen about the dangers of the housing bubble, until after she was appointed President of San Francisco Fed, well after Professor Schiller had published on the matter. So with Yellen you get the same savvy but without Summer's intellectual distinction.

Dear Regas: People have accused Larry Summers of many things, some of them justified, but lack of intestinal fortitude has been one of them. Quite to the contrary, Summer is known as political fighter and was Bob Rubin's enforcer.

Dear Cuddyroc: With great power comes the opportunity for great mistakes, and Summers has certainly made some. However, he seems to have learned from his errors and is much the better for it. Yellen, however, has had little opportunity to do good or ill.

As for the general prudence of women, the occasion, as Prof. Krugman has ceaselessly maintained on these pages, call for bold and unconventional action: “As I like to put it, virtue becomes vice and prudence becomes folly.” Krugman, supra. So, if we were to take your comment about female prudence being true--a comment which, if I had made it, would almost certainly be regarded as sexist--then a woman at the Fed would be a most unsuitable choice. However, regardless of the merits of your statement about the prudence of women, if Professor Krugman is right, that prudence is folly, then we could hardly have done better for Fed Chairman than Larry Summers.

So Summers, an academic economist of the first quality and a man who clearly understands the need for unconventional monetary and fiscal policy, had to be denied the Fed Chairmanship in favor of Janet Yellen--who, as far as I know, has never showed any shown any academic distinction as an economist--for no better reason than to have a woman as Fed Chairman. Well that is no only extreme sexism, it may well have resulted in placing a far less competent person in the Fed Chairmanship.

But on to Prof. Summer's radical view that the natural rate of interest for our economy is negative, which I think may well be correct. A negative rate of interest tells us that investing isn't and won't be profitable, unless and until the nominal rate of interest become more negative than the natural rate of interest. So how do we best achieve that?

I don't think the answer is to make it a social virtue to charge people a fee to maintain demand deposits or to maintain built in inflation much greater than at most 4%, which implies nominal negative rate of no more than -4%, which may not be enough without something more. That more should come from these areas: (1) Necessary and productive federal expenditures to restore and enhance or various communications, transportation, and other economically important infrastructures; (2) Investing in our human capital through education and training; (3) Reducing our healthcare expenditures to 9 to 10% by moving to single-payer healthcare; (cont.)

I grew up in Seattle in a neighborhood of people who had all moved there from elsewhere. Then many of the kids I grew up with also moved away, starting with college.

My grandparents (in the 1970s) lived in California. When my Dad was growing up in the 1940s, his grandparents lived several counties and many hours away, because there were no big freeways back then. My mother's grandparents were in Arkansas. When my grandparents were children in Arkansas, in the aughts, their grandparents were in North Carolina. I don't know before that.

Within my family, there have almost never been great-grandparents alive, because the generation times were between 30-40 years. Which also means now that I have small children in my 40s, my parents and my husband's parents are in their 70s. They are getting pretty old, and can't chase my two year old around. My mother-in-law has dementia in an early stage, but her reaction time is too slow to drive and she gets confused about how to light the gas stove at her house, and seems to have lost the ability to write.

So I wouldn't say it's baby boomers abdicating their responsibilities. Besides, my parents were born before World War 2 broke out, and my husband's parents were born in 1943.

As liberals never quite progressive enough for the left-most of their party, the Clintons have indeed been insufferable "Republicrats." More importantly, what the former President was suggesting didn't stop at allowing holders of sub-standard health insurance policies to keep them, but has given Republican detractors of the affordable care act an opening to offer those same "bad" policies to new enrollees, effectively nullifying a fundamental requirement of the ACA: that policy holders be covered for major medical claims in addition to the coverages provided by so-called "indemnity" policies.

Melissa Harris Perry made a great argument against the Senate's caving on this issue on MSNBC the other day. Using the analogy of "spoiled milk" she pointed out that neither the FDA nor the USDA would allow people to buy spoiled milk. Why, then, should we allow would-be health insurance enrollees to purchase sub-par coverage plans, ignoring the best advice of the government, health care insurers, and health care providers? While one or another of these entities might have a conflict of interests, I can't imagine that all of them could be dead wrong on on the actuarial realities inherent in intentionally under-insuring risks that for many of us could become future realities.

Bill Clinton, in my estimation (an independent voter), was one of the worst presidents of all time. But he does one thing very well: he reads where the political wind is blowing

He knew it was blowing for Obama in 2008 and happily rode his wife's role at 44's Secretary of State. He also knew that Obama's reelection was required for HRC to run in 2016. The only question after Obama's reelection was when to start the separation process. The debacle of the rollout of ACA along with HRC's launch of her SuperPac was his first step in separating HRC from Obama 44

Except he is politically blind to a) his wife's political shortcomings, b) how toxic the Clinton brand is and c) how much of 2016 is going to be a rejection of Wall Street, which will be exacerbated by Bill's role in repealing Glass-Steagall

The latter is a political force that has been coined Warren/Paul-ism. One coming at Wall Street from a income distribution side and the other coming at Wall Street from a pro-business/conspiracy side. Both seek the same thing. And they are the inevitable fallout from saving TBTF banks and leaving them essentially the same under Bush 43 and Obama 44

HRC fatally suffers from her brand not living up to her record. Universal Health Care. She lost and cost the DNC the House for 12 more years. No accomplishments in the Senate. Running a failed 2008 primary campaign. Nothing noteworthy as Secretary of State except for Benghazi

Add in her age and her candidacy is doomed from the start.

Her entire reign as S/S was utterly lacking in substance--her apparent goal was superficially collecting stamps on her passport. This is strikingly evident when compared to the vigorous activities of Mr. Kerry. He may not succeed on his various portfolios but he cannot be faulted for taking the most important missions, ones that really matter.

Wholeheartedly agree on HRC and S/S. The common constant in her life has been an obsession with the trappings of power and her lack of interest in organization. Said more simply: she is a sloppy want-to-be.

Sloppy in her law practice, attaining noterioty, while leaving a mess behind her. Sloppy organizing universal health care, while being more interested in her book "It Takes A Village". Sloppy vetting her vote on the Iraq war, while being more interested in a narrative that she was keeping her head down and being respected for it. Sloppy in managing her 2008 primary team, including not even knowing basic primary state calculus, while seeding her future with a narrative of a gender "glass ceiling. Sloppy in being S/S, including Benghazi and hiding, while generating what was essentially an odometer narrative.

Even sloppy in marriage, staying in a politically expedient relationship, even though everyone, but she, knows its a shameless sham.

This is not a new story. Every bit of energy she has every expended, has been to advance her credentials; leaving the "details" of organization as an after-thought.

There is nothing to suggest that the inevitable 2008 3AM candidate has matured into something else. And nothing to suggest that a back-to-the-future, soon-to-be septuagenarian is what the nation will be craving in 2016.

Using a metaphor of a book, she has already closed her chapters, and she doesn't even realize she has run out of time, and is living in her epilogue.
